elements.content: We report a 2-fold interpenetrated primitive cubic (pcu) network X-pcu-5-Zn, [Zn2­(DMTDC)2­(dpe)] (H2DMTDC = 3,4-di­meth­yl­thieno­[2,3-b]­thio­phene-2,5-di­carb­oxylic acid, dpe = 1,2-di­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene), that exhibits reversible switching between an as-synthesized “open” phase, X-pcu-5-Zn-α, and two nonporous or “closed” polymorphs, X-pcu-5-Zn-β and X-pcu-5-Zn-γ. There are two unusual features of X-pcu-5-Zn. The first relates to its sorption properties, which reveal that the α form exhibits high CO2 uptake (ca. 255 cm3/g at 195 K) via reversible closed-to-open switching (type F-IV isotherm) of the type desirable for gas and vapor storage; there are only three other reports of porous materials that combine these two features. Second, we could only isolate the β form by activation of the CO2 loaded α form and it persists through multiple CO2 adsorption/desorption cycles. We are unaware of a new polymorph having been isolated in such a manner. That the observed phase changes of X-pcu-5-Zn-α occur in single-crystal-to-single-crystal fashion enabled structural characterization of the three forms; γ is a coordination isomer of α and β, both of which are based upon “paddlewheel” clusters.
elements.clean_text: We report a 2-fold interpenetrated primitive cubic (pcu) network X-pcu-5-Zn, [Zn2(DMTDC)2(dpe)] (H2DMTDC = 3,4-dimethylthieno[2,3-b]thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid, dpe = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene), that exhibits reversible switching between an as-synthesized "open" phase, X-pcu-5-Zn-α, and two nonporous or "closed" polymorphs, X-pcu-5-Zn-β and X-pcu-5-Zn-γ. There are two unusual features of X-pcu-5-Zn. The first relates to its sorption properties, which reveal that the α form exhibits high CO2 uptake (ca. 255 cm3/g at 195 K) via reversible closed-to-open switching (type F-IV isotherm) of the type desirable for gas and vapor storage; there are only three other reports of porous materials that combine these two features. Second, we could only isolate the β form by activation of the CO2 loaded α form and it persists through multiple CO2 adsorption/desorption cycles. We are unaware of a new polymorph having been isolated in such a manner. That the observed phase changes of X-pcu-5-Zn-α occur in single-crystal-to-single-crystal fashion enabled structural characterization of the three forms; γ is a coordination isomer of α and β, both of which are based upon "paddlewheel" clusters.

elements.content: That we are in the “Age of Gas” requires development of more energy efficient technologies for gas storage and/or delivery. Considerable attention has been directed toward the use of porous crystalline adsorbents with high surface area as an alternative to existing energy intensive technologies such as compression and liquefaction. Metal–organic materials (MOMs), especially metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and porous coordination polymers (PCPs), have emerged as a class of porous materials that offers great potential for gas storage/delivery applications, especially natural gas (NG) storage. They are of interest thanks to their modularity, high porosity and pore tunability. However, no rigid MOM yet meets the requisite properties for practical deployment in NG storage applications owing to reduced working capacity that results from the type I isotherms characteristic of microporous materials. Flexible MOMs (FMOMs) offer a potential solution to this problem as they can “breathe”, i.e., contract under reduced gas pressure and expand under increased pressure. Consequently, they tend to exhibit “S-shaped” or stepped adsorption isotherms that result from guest-induced structural transitions. Such adsorption isotherms can enhance working capacity between the storage and deliverable pressures. However, although there are >20 000 porous MOMs reported in the literature, most of them are rigid physisorbents with type-I sorption isotherms. Our survey of the literature revealed ca. 150 FMOMs and most transform between less open (small pore) and more open (large pore) phases (Type F-I and Type F-II isotherms). Unfortunately, such isotherms offer little advantage over Type I isotherms as they retain adsorbate at low (deliverable) pressure. FMOMs with Type F-IV isotherms that switch between nonporous and porous phases represent the most desirable type for pressure swing adsorption (PSA) gas storage. Unfortunately, there are very few reports of FMOMs with Type F–IV isotherms. Indeed, only DUT-8­(Ni), X-dia-1-Ni and Co­(bdp) (bdp2– = 1,4-benzenedipyrazolate) exhibit porous phases with saturation uptake >250 cm3/g. Further, multiple cycles of adsorption/desorption cause the gate-opening pressure of DUT-8­(Ni) to shift and X-dia-1-Ni to degrade. In addition, X-dia-1-Ni exhibits strong hysteresis which can also reduce the working capacity. Co­(bdp) (bdp2– = 1,4-benzenedipyrazolate) is the only FMOM with both high working capacity and good recyclability yet it must be handled in a glovebox. Herein, we introduce a new FMOM that meets the aforementioned criteria, [Zn2­(DMTDC)2­(dpe)] (X-pcu-5-Zn, ).
elements.clean_text: That we are in the "Age of Gas" requires development of more energy efficient technologies for gas storage and/or delivery. Considerable attention has been directed toward the use of porous crystalline adsorbents with high surface area as an alternative to existing energy intensive technologies such as compression and liquefaction. Metal-organic materials (MOMs), especially metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and porous coordination polymers (PCPs), have emerged as a class of porous materials that offers great potential for gas storage/delivery applications, especially natural gas (NG) storage. They are of interest thanks to their modularity, high porosity and pore tunability. However, no rigid MOM yet meets the requisite properties for practical deployment in NG storage applications owing to reduced working capacity that results from the type I isotherms characteristic of microporous materials. Flexible MOMs (FMOMs) offer a potential solution to this problem as they can "breathe", i.e., contract under reduced gas pressure and expand under increased pressure. Consequently, they tend to exhibit "S-shaped" or stepped adsorption isotherms that result from guest-induced structural transitions. Such adsorption isotherms can enhance working capacity between the storage and deliverable pressures. However, although there are >20000 porous MOMs reported in the literature, most of them are rigid physisorbents with type-I sorption isotherms. Our survey of the literature revealed ca. 150 FMOMs and most transform between less open (small pore) and more open (large pore) phases (Type F-I and Type F-II isotherms). Unfortunately, such isotherms offer little advantage over Type I isotherms as they retain adsorbate at low (deliverable) pressure. FMOMs with Type F-IV isotherms that switch between nonporous and porous phases represent the most desirable type for pressure swing adsorption (PSA) gas storage. Unfortunately, there are very few reports of FMOMs with Type F-IV isotherms. Indeed, only DUT-8(Ni), X-dia-1-Ni  and Co(bdp) (bdp2- = 1,4-benzenedipyrazolate) exhibit porous phases with saturation uptake >250 cm3/g. Further, multiple cycles of adsorption/desorption cause the gate-opening pressure of DUT-8(Ni) to shift and X-dia-1-Ni to degrade. In addition, X-dia-1-Ni exhibits strong hysteresis which can also reduce the working capacity. Co(bdp) (bdp2- = 1,4-benzenedipyrazolate) is the only FMOM with both high working capacity and good recyclability yet it must be handled in a glovebox. Herein, we introduce a new FMOM that meets the aforementioned criteria, [Zn2(DMTDC)2(dpe)] (X-pcu-5-Zn, ).

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Structural Transformations of <bold>X-pcu-5-Zn</bold>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr4" position="float" xlink:href="ja-2018-08642n_0004.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Solvothermal reaction of H2DMTDC and dpe with Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O in DMF at 105 °C afforded pale yellow, rod shaped crystals of X-pcu-5-Zn·3DMF·0.5H2O (see (SI)), X-pcu-5-Zn-α. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) revealed that X-pcu-5-Zn-α crystallized in triclinic space group P-1. The structure is comprised of dinuclear Zn­(II) tetracarboxylate paddlewheels linked via DMTDC ligands to form a square lattice, sql, network (a). The sql nets are pillared by dpe linkers to afford a pcu topology net. X-pcu-5-Zn-α is therefore a variant of DMOF-1 with 2-fold offset interpenetration. X-pcu-5-Zn-α exhibits 1D channels with an effective pore diameter of ca. 5.1 × 4.6 Å along the c-axis () and calculated guest-accessible volume of 45.7%. TGA revealed that as-synthesized X-pcu-5-Zn-α loses guest molecules (obs. 21.86%; cal. 21.74%) by 110 °C and is stable to 320 °C ().
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reaction of H2DMTDC and dpe with Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in DMF at 105 °C afforded pale yellow, rod shaped crystals of X-pcu-5-Zn⋅3DMF⋅0.5H2O (see  (SI)), X-pcu-5-Zn-α. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) revealed that X-pcu-5-Zn-α crystallized in triclinic space group P-1. The structure is comprised of dinuclear Zn(II) tetracarboxylate paddlewheels linked via DMTDC ligands to form a square lattice, sql, network (a). The sql nets are pillared by dpe linkers to afford a pcu topology net. X-pcu-5-Zn-α is therefore a variant of DMOF-1 with 2-fold offset interpenetration. X-pcu-5-Zn-α exhibits 1D channels with an effective pore diameter of ca. 5.1 × 4.6 Å along the c-axis () and calculated guest-accessible volume of 45.7%. TGA revealed that as-synthesized X-pcu-5-Zn-α loses guest molecules (obs. 21.86%; cal. 21.74%) by 110 °C and is stable to 320 °C ().

elements.content: Crystal structures of the α (a), β (b) and γ (c) forms of X-pcu-5-Zn reveal zinc clusters (left) and sql nets constructed by the clusters and DMTDC ligands (right). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. C (gray), Zn (green), O (red), N (blue), S (yellow).
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structures of the α (a), β (b) and γ (c) forms of X-pcu-5-Zn reveal zinc clusters (left) and sql nets constructed by the clusters and DMTDC ligands (right). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. C (gray), Zn (green), O (red), N (blue), S (yellow).

elements.content: X-pcu-5-Zn-α underwent a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation following methanol exchange for 1 day and evacuation to form X-pcu-5-Zn-β (). SCXRD revealed that the β form is a contorted version of the α form with the same connectivity (b) but centered interpenetration. X-pcu-5-Zn-β crystallized in Cmca with 33.6% shrinkage of its unit-cell volume relative to the α form (). TGA and IR studies indicated that guest release occurs under ambient conditions after methanol exchange (). The structural transformation associated with guest release is reversible; the β form reverts to the α form when soaked in DMF at room temperature for 1 day ().
elements.clean_text: X-pcu-5-Zn-α underwent a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation following methanol exchange for 1 day and evacuation to form X-pcu-5-Zn-β (). SCXRD revealed that the β form is a contorted version of the α form with the same connectivity (b) but centered interpenetration. X-pcu-5-Zn-β crystallized in Cmca with 33.6% shrinkage of its unit-cell volume relative to the α form (). TGA and IR studies indicated that guest release occurs under ambient conditions after methanol exchange (). The structural transformation associated with guest release is reversible; the β form reverts to the α form when soaked in DMF at room temperature for 1 day ().

elements.content: Heating the α or β forms afforded X-pcu-5-Zn-γ (). The γ form is also a nonporous 2-fold interpenetrated pcu net, but with different coordination geometry. X-pcu-5-Zn, unlike related compounds, does not transform to a phase with a higher level of interpenetration, which we attribute to the length of the DMTDC linker. X-pcu-5-Zn-γ crystallized in Pbca and had undergone 33.5% shrinkage relative to the α form. The zinc cations in the γ form adopt tetrahedral coordination geometry from three monodentate carboxylate ligands and a pyridyl moiety. The sql net is once again distorted into a rhombus (c) and the interpenetration is centered ( and ). PLATON calculations revealed that the γ phase is nonporous. TGA of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ revealed no weight loss until decomposition at 320 °C (). Despite bond breakage, the γ form readily reverted to the α form when soaked in DMF at room temperature for 1 d (). X-pcu-5-Zn-γ was stable in air after exposure to 75% relative humidity () with little water vapor uptake at 298 K (). The crystal structures are analyzed in and .
elements.clean_text: Heating the α or β forms afforded X-pcu-5-Zn-γ (). The γ form is also a nonporous 2-fold interpenetrated pcu net, but with different coordination geometry. X-pcu-5-Zn, unlike related compounds, does not transform to a phase with a higher level of interpenetration, which we attribute to the length of the DMTDC linker. X-pcu-5-Zn-γ crystallized in Pbca and had undergone 33.5% shrinkage relative to the α form. The zinc cations in the γ form adopt tetrahedral coordination geometry from three monodentate carboxylate ligands and a pyridyl moiety. The sql net is once again distorted into a rhombus (c) and the interpenetration is centered ( and ). PLATON calculations revealed that the γ phase is nonporous. TGA of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ revealed no weight loss until decomposition at 320 °C (). Despite bond breakage, the γ form readily reverted to the α form when soaked in DMF at room temperature for 1 d (). X-pcu-5-Zn-γ was stable in air after exposure to 75% relative humidity () with little water vapor uptake at 298 K (). The crystal structures are analyzed in  and .

elements.content: That X-pcu-5-Zn-β and X-pcu-5-Zn-γ are nonporous but prepared from a porous phase suggested to us that they might exhibit switching to X-pcu-5-Zn-α when exposed to gases. The β form indeed exhibited gate-opening for N2 at 77 K with an onset pressure of 340 mmHg, but saturation was not attained with uptake of 136 cm3/g at 745 mmHg (a). The CO2 sorption isotherm at 195 K displayed switching behavior (227 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.30) with saturation (ca. 250 cm3) at 0.6 bar. In contrast, the γ form exhibited no N2 (77 K) induced switching up to 1 bar. CO2 (195 K) sorption revealed a Type F-IV isotherm and saturated uptake (256 cm3/g at 1 bar, gate-opening pressure of 272 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.36) (b). Adsorption kinetics were observed to be slower than desorption (). Pore volumes of 0.45 and 0.46 cm3/g for the β and γ forms were calculated by assuming liquid filling of CO2 when saturated. These values are close to the 0.43 cm3/g estimated from the crystal structure of X-pcu-5-Zn-α. The Langmuir surface areas for the α form calculated from the CO2 sorption isotherms of the β and γ forms at 195 K are 1318 and 1441 m2 g–1, respectively. The desorption isotherms exhibit hysteresis with adsorbed CO2 retained for both the β and γ phases around 183 mmHg (P/P 0 = 0.24). Other FMOMs that exhibit single step Type F–IV isotherms are tabulated in ; DUT-8 exhibits similar switching pressures. Most CO2 isotherms for FMOMs exhibit several steps or one step with a much lower closing pressure. Such stepped isotherms are rare and are yet to be classified by IUPAC. That X-pcu-5-Zn exhibits high CO2 uptake (ca. 255 cm3/g) makes it one of only four FMOMs that exhibit both a Type F-IV isotherm and a saturation uptake >250 cm3/g.

The β form indeed exhibited gate-opening for N2 at 77 K with an onset pressure of 340 mmHg, but saturation was not attained with uptake of 136 cm3/g at 745 mmHg (a). In contrast, the γ form exhibited no N2 (77 K) induced switching up to 1 bar. CO2 (195 K) sorption revealed a Type F-IV isotherm and saturated uptake (256 cm3/g at 1 bar, gate-opening pressure of 272 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.36) (b). Adsorption kinetics were observed to be slower than desorption (). Pore volumes of 0.45 and 0.46 cm3/g for the β and γ forms were calculated by assuming liquid filling of CO2 when saturated. These values are close to the 0.43 cm3/g estimated from the crystal structure of X-pcu-5-Zn-α. The desorption isotherms exhibit hysteresis with adsorbed CO2 retained for both the β and γ phases around 183 mmHg (P/P 0 = 0.24). Other FMOMs that exhibit single step Type F-IV isotherms are tabulated in ; DUT-8 exhibits similar switching pressures. Most CO2 isotherms for FMOMs exhibit several steps or one step with a much lower closing pressure. Such stepped isotherms are rare and are yet to be classified by IUPAC. That X-pcu-5-Zn exhibits high CO2 uptake (ca. 255 cm3/g) makes it one of only four FMOMs that exhibit both a Type F-IV isotherm and a saturation uptake >250 cm3/g.

elements.content: (a) Gas sorption isotherms of X-pcu-5-Zn-β at 77K (N2) and at 195 K (CO2). (b) Gas sorption isotherms of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 77K (N2) and at 195 K (CO2). (c) PXRD patterns of X-pcu-Zn-β under different conditions. (d) PXRD patterns of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ under different conditions. (e) Five consecutive cycles of CO2 sorption of X-pcu-5-Zn-β at 195 K. (f) Five consecutive cycles of CO2 sorption of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 195 K. Inset: the structural transformation accompanying CO2 adsorption and desorption.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Gas sorption isotherms of X-pcu-5-Zn-β at 77K (N2) and at 195 K (CO2). (b) Gas sorption isotherms of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 77K (N2) and at 195 K (CO2). (c) PXRD patterns of X-pcu-Zn-β under different conditions. (d) PXRD patterns of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ under different conditions. (e) Five consecutive cycles of CO2 sorption of X-pcu-5-Zn-β at 195 K. (f) Five consecutive cycles of CO2 sorption of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 195 K. Inset: the structural transformation accompanying CO2 adsorption and desorption.

elements.content: PXRD indicated that X-pcu-5-Zn-β was recovered after N2 or CO2 sorption (c) whereas X-pcu-5-Zn-γ had transformed to X-pcu-5-Zn-β after CO2 desorption (d). Reversible Zn–carboxylate bond rearrangement induced by gases has been reported, but to our knowledge X-pcu-5-Zn-γ is the first example induced by CO2. To further investigate these transformations, five consecutive cycles of CO2 adsorption at 195 K were conducted for the β and γ forms (e and f). The switching onset pressure for the first run of X-pcu-5-Zn-β is slightly higher than that of the remaining cycles. Previous reports indicate that this observation could be the result of a phase change during degassing (). Alternatively, Long and co-workers suggested that a slightly higher energy barrier might be required for the first expansion of a freshly packed sample. Nevertheless, saturation uptakes and desorption profiles for all cycles are equivalent. The corresponding cycles for X-pcu-5-Zn-γ reveal that the gate opening pressure for the second cycle (216 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.28) is below that of the first cycle (272 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.36, f). The stress of multiple sorption cycles resulted in reduction in crystallite size (), but adsorption capacity was unaffected. X-pcu-5-Zn-β obtained from exposure of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ to CO2 is unstable in air overnight (), partially reverting to X-pcu-5-Zn-γ.
elements.clean_text: PXRD indicated that X-pcu-5-Zn-β was recovered after N2 or CO2 sorption (c) whereas X-pcu-5-Zn-γ had transformed to X-pcu-5-Zn-β after CO2 desorption (d). Reversible Zn-carboxylate bond rearrangement induced by gases has been reported, but to our knowledge X-pcu-5-Zn-γ is the first example induced by CO2. To further investigate these transformations, five consecutive cycles of CO2 adsorption at 195 K were conducted for the β and γ forms (e and f). The switching onset pressure for the first run of X-pcu-5-Zn-β is slightly higher than that of the remaining cycles. Previous reports indicate that this observation could be the result of a phase change during degassing (). Alternatively, Long and co-workers suggested that a slightly higher energybarrier might be required for the first expansion of a freshly packed sample. Nevertheless, saturation uptakes and desorption profiles for all cycles are equivalent. The corresponding cycles for X-pcu-5-Zn-γ reveal that the gate opening pressure for the second cycle (216 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.28) is below that of the first cycle (272 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.36, f). The stress of multiple sorption cycles resulted in reduction in crystallite size (), but adsorption capacity was unaffected. X-pcu-5-Zn-β obtained from exposure of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ to CO2 is unstable in air overnight (), partially reverting to X-pcu-5-Zn-γ.

elements.content: DSC measurement of X-pcu-5-Zn-β after methanol exchange revealed a broad exotherm at 150 °C () suggestive of a polymorphic transformation. PXRD measurements confirmed that the β form and γ form are monotropic polymorphs­(). X-pcu-5-Zn-γ obtained by heating the β form or the CO2-loaded α form also displayed Type F–IV isotherms (). These samples also converted to the β form after CO2 desorption (). Polymorphic transformations of nonporous solids induced by pressure are well-known, but we are unaware of phase transformations via an intermediate porous phase, as is the case herein.
elements.clean_text: DSC measurement of X-pcu-5-Zn-β after methanol exchange revealed a broad exotherm at 150 °C () suggestive of a polymorphic transformation. PXRD measurements confirmed that the β form and γ form are monotropic polymorphs(). X-pcu-5-Zn-γ obtained by heating the β form or the CO2-loaded α form also displayed Type F-IV isotherms (). These samples also converted to the β form after CO2 desorption (). Polymorphic transformations of nonporous solids induced by pressure are well-known, but we are unaware of phase transformations via an intermediate porous phase, as is the case herein.

elements.content: High-pressure CO2 sorption at 268 K was performed on X-pcu-5-Zn-γ (). Once more, the gate adsorption pressure of the first cycle (P = 18.6 bar) differed from subsequent cycles (P = 15.6 bar), which remained constant even after >30 cycles and downsizing (). PXRD indicated that the γ form converted to the β form after multiple cycles of CO2 absorption/desorption (). Raman spectra () are diagnostic of these phase changes. The α form exhibits bands at 1420 and 1404 cm–1 corresponding to νsym(COO–) vibration whereas the β form also exhibits a small peak at 1397 cm–1 and a larger peak at 1422 cm–1. A single band at 1419 cm–1 was measured for X-pcu-5-Zn-γ. After both low and high-pressure CO2 sorption/desorption cycles, the Raman bands of X-pcu-Zn-5-γ became consistent with X-pcu-5-Zn-β.
elements.clean_text: High-pressure CO2 sorption at 268 K was performed on X-pcu-5-Zn-γ (). Once more, the gate adsorption pressure of the first cycle (P = 18.6 bar) differed from subsequent cycles (P = 15.6 bar), which remained constant even after >30 cycles and downsizing (). PXRD indicated that the γ form converted to the β form after multiple cycles of CO2 absorption/desorption (). Raman spectra () are diagnostic of these phase changes. The α form exhibits bands at 1420 and 1404 cm-1 corresponding to νsym(COO-) vibration whereas the β form also exhibits a small peak at 1397 cm-1 and a larger peak at 1422 cm-1. A single band at 1419 cm-1 was measured for X-pcu-5-Zn-γ. After both low and high-pressure CO2 sorption/desorption cycles, the Raman bands of X-pcu-Zn-5-γ became consistent with X-pcu-5-Zn-β.

elements.content: (a) High-pressure CO2 sorption isotherms for X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 268 K obtained during cyclic sorption studies and the accompanying structural transformations. (b) Recyclability test for X-pcu-Zn-γ at 268 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) High-pressure CO2 sorption isotherms for X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 268 K obtained during cyclic sorption studies and the accompanying structural transformations. (b) Recyclability test for X-pcu-Zn-γ at 268 K.

elements.content: The single crystal structures of X-pcu-5-Zn-α, X-pcu-5-Zn-β and X-pcu-5-Zn-γ revealed sliding of the two interpenetrated nets and distortion of the sql nets () accompanied transformation between the closed phases and the porous phase. There are no π–π interactions (centroid–centroid distance are >4.0 Å) in any phase but C–H-π interactions exist in the α phase (). C–H···O interactions between interpenetrated nets exist in the α and γ forms (), but there are no such interactions in the β form. Others have suggested that framework flexibility can be associated with sliding of interpenetrated nets, rotation and distortion of organic linkers, and/or reorientation of coordination bonds. These features are observed herein.
elements.clean_text: The single crystal structures of X-pcu-5-Zn-α, X-pcu-5-Zn-β and X-pcu-5-Zn-γ revealed sliding of the two interpenetrated nets and distortion of the sql nets () accompanied transformation between the closed phases and the porous phase. There are no π-π interactions (centroid-centroid distance are >4.0 Å) in any phase but C-H-π interactions exist in the α phase (). C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions between interpenetrated nets exist in the α and γ forms (), but there are no such interactions in the β form. Others have suggested that framework flexibility can be associated with sliding of interpenetrated nets, rotation and distortion of organic linkers, and/or reorientation of coordination bonds. These features are observed herein.

elements.content: In summary, we report a flexible, 2-fold interpenetrated coordination network, X-pcu-5-Zn, with three crystal forms, two of which are nonporous polymorphs. There are three primary messages from this study. First, the β form represents to our knowledge the first example of polymorph discovery by desorption. Given the importance of polymorphism in pharmaceutical compounds, the approach used herein could supplement crystallization screens to discover new polymorphs. Second, the two closed forms, β and γ, exhibit type F-IV isotherms with CO2 uptakes >250 cm3/g at cryogenic temperatures and survive multiple adsorption/desorption cycles. X-pcu-5-Zn is therefore only the second example of an FMOM that exhibits a type F-IV isotherm with uptake capacity of >250 cm3/g and it is recyclable over multiple cycles. Third, X-pcu-5-Zn is a variant of DMOF-1; as such, it belongs to one of the most compositionally diverse platforms of coordination networks and we have recently reported on related coordination networks that also exhibit multiple phase transformations. Many related compounds with multiple phases are anticipated based upon these observations.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we report a flexible, 2-fold interpenetrated coordination network, X-pcu-5-Zn, with three crystal forms, two of which are nonporous polymorphs. There are three primary messages from this study. First, the β form represents to our knowledge the first example of polymorph discovery by desorption. Given the importance of polymorphism in pharmaceutical compounds, the approach used herein could supplement crystallization screens to discover new polymorphs. Second, the two closed forms, β and γ, exhibit type F-IV isotherms with CO2 uptakes >250 cm3/g at cryogenic temperatures and survive multiple adsorption/desorption cycles. X-pcu-5-Zn is therefore only the second example of an FMOM that exhibits a type F-IV isotherm with uptake capacity of >250 cm3/g and it is recyclable over multiple cycles. Third, X-pcu-5-Zn is a variant of DMOF-1; as such, it belongs to one of the most compositionally diverse platforms of coordination networks and we have recently reported on related coordination networks that also exhibit multiple phase transformations. Many related compounds with multiple phases are anticipated based upon these observations.

cln_elements.content: That X-pcu-5-Zn-β and X-pcu-5-Zn-γ are nonporous but prepared from a porous phase suggested to us that they might exhibit switching to X-pcu-5-Zn-α when exposed to gases. The β form indeed exhibited gate-opening for N2 at 77 K with an onset pressure of 340 mmHg, but saturation was not attained with uptake of 136 cm3/g at 745 mmHg (a). The CO2 sorption isotherm at 195 K displayed switching behavior (227 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.30) with saturation (ca. 250 cm3) at 0.6 bar. In contrast, the γ form exhibited no N2 (77 K) induced switching up to 1 bar. CO2 (195 K) sorption revealed a Type F-IV isotherm and saturated uptake (256 cm3/g at 1 bar, gate-opening pressure of 272 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.36) (b). Adsorption kinetics were observed to be slower than desorption (). Pore volumes of 0.45 and 0.46 cm3/g for the β and γ forms were calculated by assuming liquid filling of CO2 when saturated. These values are close to the 0.43 cm3/g estimated from the crystal structure of X-pcu-5-Zn-α. The Langmuir surface areas for the α form calculated from the CO2 sorption isotherms of the β and γ forms at 195 K are 1318 and 1441 m2 g–1, respectively. The desorption isotherms exhibit hysteresis with adsorbed CO2 retained for both the β and γ phases around 183 mmHg (P/P 0 = 0.24). Other FMOMs that exhibit single step Type F–IV isotherms are tabulated in ; DUT-8 exhibits similar switching pressures. Most CO2 isotherms for FMOMs exhibit several steps or one step with a much lower closing pressure. Such stepped isotherms are rare and are yet to be classified by IUPAC. That X-pcu-5-Zn exhibits high CO2 uptake (ca. 255 cm3/g) makes it one of only four FMOMs that exhibit both a Type F-IV isotherm and a saturation uptake >250 cm3/g.

The β form indeed exhibited gate-opening for N2 at 77 K with an onset pressure of 340 mmHg, but saturation was not attained with uptake of 136 cm3/g at 745 mmHg (a). In contrast, the γ form exhibited no N2 (77 K) induced switching up to 1 bar. CO2 (195 K) sorption revealed a Type F-IV isotherm and saturated uptake (256 cm3/g at 1 bar, gate-opening pressure of 272 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.36) (b). Adsorption kinetics were observed to be slower than desorption (). Pore volumes of 0.45 and 0.46 cm3/g for the β and γ forms were calculated by assuming liquid filling of CO2 when saturated. These values are close to the 0.43 cm3/g estimated from the crystal structure of X-pcu-5-Zn-α. The Langmuir surface areas for the α form calculated from the CO2 sorption isotherms of the β and γ forms at 195 K are 1318 and 1441 m2 g-1, respectively. The desorption isotherms exhibit hysteresis with adsorbed CO2 retained for both the β and γ phases around 183 mmHg (P/P 0 = 0.24). Other FMOMs that exhibit single step Type F-IV isotherms are tabulated in ; DUT-8 exhibits similar switching pressures. Most CO2 isotherms for FMOMs exhibit several steps or one step with a much lower closing pressure. Such stepped isotherms are rare and are yet to be classified by IUPAC. That X-pcu-5-Zn exhibits high CO2 uptake (ca. 255 cm3/g) makes it one of only four FMOMs that exhibit both a Type F-IV isotherm and a saturation uptake >250 cm3/g.

gas adsorption.condition: Type F-IV isotherm, gate-opening pressure of 272 mmHg, P/P 0 = 0.36
Type F-IV isotherm and a saturation uptake >250 cm3/g

cln_elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Structural Transformations of <bold>X-pcu-5-Zn</bold>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr4" position="float" xlink:href="ja-2018-08642n_0004.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Crystal structures of the α (a), β (b) and γ (c) forms of X-pcu-5-Zn reveal zinc clusters (left) and sql nets constructed by the clusters and DMTDC ligands (right). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. C (gray), Zn (green), O (red), N (blue), S (yellow).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structures of the α (a), β (b) and γ (c) forms of X-pcu-5-Zn reveal zinc clusters (left) and sql nets constructed by the clusters and DMTDC ligands (right). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. C (gray), Zn (green), O (red), N (blue), S (yellow).

cln_elements.content: (a) Gas sorption isotherms of X-pcu-5-Zn-β at 77K (N2) and at 195 K (CO2). (b) Gas sorption isotherms of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 77K (N2) and at 195 K (CO2). (c) PXRD patterns of X-pcu-Zn-β under different conditions. (d) PXRD patterns of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ under different conditions. (e) Five consecutive cycles of CO2 sorption of X-pcu-5-Zn-β at 195 K. (f) Five consecutive cycles of CO2 sorption of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 195 K. Inset: the structural transformation accompanying CO2 adsorption and desorption.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Gas sorption isotherms of X-pcu-5-Zn-β at 77K (N2) and at 195 K (CO2). (b) Gas sorption isotherms of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 77K (N2) and at 195 K (CO2). (c) PXRD patterns of X-pcu-Zn-β under different conditions. (d) PXRD patterns of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ under different conditions. (e) Five consecutive cycles of CO2 sorption of X-pcu-5-Zn-β at 195 K. (f) Five consecutive cycles of CO2 sorption of X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 195 K. Inset: the structural transformation accompanying CO2 adsorption and desorption.

cln_elements.content: (a) High-pressure CO2 sorption isotherms for X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 268 K obtained during cyclic sorption studies and the accompanying structural transformations. (b) Recyclability test for X-pcu-Zn-γ at 268 K.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) High-pressure CO2 sorption isotherms for X-pcu-5-Zn-γ at 268 K obtained during cyclic sorption studies and the accompanying structural transformations. (b) Recyclability test for X-pcu-Zn-γ at 268 K.

metadata.title:
Coordination
Network That Reversibly Switches between
Two Nonporous Polymorphs and a High Surface Area Porous Phase
